description: Pomegranate is a fruit-bearing shrub or small tree native to the Middle East and South Asia. Known for its juicy red seeds, pomegranate is a rich source of antioxidants and vitamin C, often used in juices, salads, and culinary dishes. The plant thrives in arid and semi-arid regions and is valued for its health benefits.

climate.watering: Pomegranates are drought-tolerant but perform best with moderate irrigation, especially during fruit development. Overwatering can cause root rot and fungal diseases.

symptoms: Dark brown to black spots with yellow margins on leaves.
Lesions on fruit with dark, sunken spots.

background.cause: A fungal disease caused by *Alternaria alternata* that affects the leaves, fruits, and stems of pomegranate plants.
background.spread_by: Wind, rain, and infected plant debris.

cure: Apply fungicides like Mancozeb or Azoxystrobin.
Remove and destroy infected plant parts to reduce spread.
Ensure good air circulation and avoid overhead watering.
diseases.fertilizers: Use balanced fertilizers, especially nitrogen, to support plant health and improve resistance to fungal diseases.
prevention: Plant in well-drained soils with proper spacing between plants.
Apply preventive fungicides before wet seasons.
Practice crop rotation to reduce pathogen buildup.

symptoms: Dark, sunken lesions on fruits, often leading to soft rot.
Black streaks and spots on stems and leaves.

background.cause: A fungal disease caused by *Colletotrichum gloeosporioides*, affecting both fruit and vegetative parts of the plant.
background.spread_by: Infected seeds, contaminated tools, and environmental conditions like high humidity.

cure: Apply fungicides like Chlorothalonil or Carbendazim.
Remove infected fruits and leaves to prevent further spread.
Improve plant spacing for better air circulation.
diseases.fertilizers: Avoid excessive nitrogen application, which can favor fungal growth. Use balanced fertilizers for overall plant health.
prevention: Ensure proper field sanitation by removing plant debris.
Use disease-resistant pomegranate varieties where available.
Maintain proper irrigation techniques to avoid wetting the foliage.

symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves, followed by yellowing and necrosis.
Browning and splitting of stems and branches.
Reduced plant vigor and poor fruit quality.

background.cause: A bacterial disease caused by *Xanthomonas axonopodis*, which affects pomegranate leaves, stems, and fruits.
background.spread_by: Rain, irrigation water, infected tools, and splashing water.

cure: Use copper-based bactericides like Copper Hydroxide.
Prune infected branches and disinfect tools to reduce spread.
Avoid overhead irrigation to prevent bacterial spread.
diseases.fertilizers: Balanced fertilizers, especially potassium, should be used to improve resistance to bacterial infections.
prevention: Plant in well-drained soils with good air circulation.
Implement regular field sanitation and avoid waterlogging.

symptoms: Circular, dark brown lesions on the upper side of leaves.
Yellow halo around the lesions, causing premature leaf drop.
Reduced photosynthetic capacity and stunted plant growth.

background.cause: A fungal disease caused by *Cercospora punicae*, affecting mainly the leaves and leading to reduced vigor.

cure: Spray with fungicides like Copper Oxychloride or Thiophanate Methyl.
Remove infected leaves to reduce the source of infection.
Avoid high humidity and overcrowded plants.
diseases.fertilizers: Apply balanced fertilizers with emphasis on potassium to reduce disease susceptibility.
prevention: Practice crop rotation and avoid planting pomegranates in areas with a history of fungal diseases.
Ensure proper plant spacing to promote airflow and reduce humidity.

preventive_practices: Regularly monitor plants for early signs of fungal and bacterial infections.
Apply fungicides preventively during wet conditions to reduce disease spread.
Ensure proper spacing to allow adequate airflow and reduce humidity around the plants.
Remove and destroy infected plant material to limit disease spread.
Use certified disease-free seeds and resistant varieties when available.
